<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Saturday means another edition of the New Normal, Morning Brew's series that explores the pandemic's long-term effects on various industries. <div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SAVINGS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/19/us-savings-rate-highest-recordwhy-thats-not-necessarily-good-thing?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The United States of Hoarders
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Napoleon Dynamite" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=363 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/YRo3S2P600PicZhNKX/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Napoleon Dynamite" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/YRo3S2P600PicZhNKX/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We know we were supposed to write a story about consumer spending during the pandemic, but...that’d just be lying to y’all. Here’s the reality: Americans aren’t spending squat during the pandemic. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The U.S. savings rate <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/29/us-savings-rate-hits-record-33percent-as-coronavirus-causes-americans-to-stockpile-cash-curb-spending.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rose to 33%</a> in April, the highest level on record and it’s not even close. At the same time, consumer spending fell 13.6% (also a record). There are a few reasons why this happened:</p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>There’s nothing to spend money on. Office work, events, sports, conferences, vacations, weddings, birthday parties, and more were all canceled.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Stimulus checks of up to $1,200 hit millions of households, driving up personal income to record levels.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>With unemployment at 13.3%, Americans are feeling nervous about their job prospects.</span></li>
</ol>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">But not all Americans saved equally</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Findings from a Harvard-based research group show that high-income Americans are responsible for <a href="https://opportunityinsights.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/tracker-summary.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">most of the reduction</a> in consumer spending. Lower-income Americans, on the other hand, are now spending nearly as much as they did pre-pandemic—but they’re suffering as the rich hoard their wealth.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Almost 70% of low-wage workers working in the highest-rent ZIP codes lost their jobs, the researchers note.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why it matters: </strong>It further confirms that this recession is one of the weirdest ever. In past downturns people stopped spending on big-ticket items like cars, while keeping up their spending on basic services. That’s flipped this time around, because many of those services (like haircuts) require in-person interactions that can lead to the spread of the virus.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Looking ahead</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The research is telling us something very important: even if government restrictions were lifted, Americans still wouldn't be spending at pre-pandemic levels out of fear for their health. Which means the NFL could announce tomorrow it’s allowing fans to attend games this season and not many would bite. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Consumer spending drives nearly 70% of U.S. GDP, so an elevated savings rate could be <a href="https://carnegieendowment.org/chinafinancialmarkets/81871?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">detrimental</a> to the economy in the long-run. After all, writes the Carnegie Endowment, one person’s spending is another person’s income. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GROCERY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/19/can-grocery-deliverys-growth-spurt-last?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Can Grocery Delivery's Growth Spurt Last?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Grocery delivery worker" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNDI5L2dyb2NlcnlfZGVsaXZlcnlfd29ya2VyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Rob Kim/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Online grocery sales <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-27/has-online-grocery-shopping-peaked-most-still-prefer-in-store?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rose 200%</a> year-over-year in March, according to Earnest Research, with Walmart, Amazon, and Instacart all reporting dramatic increases in demand. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>“The customer demand we expected over the next two-to-four years on the Instacart platform has happened in the last two-to-four weeks,” said Instacart’s CEO in early April.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Some results of that surge:</strong> 1) Instacart nabbed a <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/jenniferwang/2020/06/17/instacart-founder-apoorva-mehta-becomes-a-billionaire/#6898a9997e02?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$13.7 billion</a> valuation in a recent funding round and 2) Whole Foods and others <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/04/how-youll-shop-for-groceries-after-the-pandemic/610135/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rushed</a> to transition some locations to “dark stores,” micro-fulfillment centers intended exclusively for delivery orders, not in-person shopping. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">As COVID-19 restrictions ease...</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Many shoppers want to resume playing ripe-avocado roulette in person. CivicScience and Bloomberg found that over one-third of shoppers plan to order groceries online less often as restrictions ease up. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But even as shoppers head back to stores, more have discovered online delivery for the first time and now have the apps on their phones. Kroger CEO Rodney McMullen said this week he thinks habits around home cooking have <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/kroger-ceo-talks-earnings-digital-172204451.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">permanently changed</a> because of the coronavirus. And after hiring 40,000 new employees exclusively for online shopping, his company now has the infrastructure necessary to handle more digital orders. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F06%2F19%2Fcan-grocery-deliverys-growth-spurt-last" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>
<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Online+grocery+sales+rose+200%25+year-over-year+in+March&url=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/19/can-grocery-deliverys-growth-spurt-last&via=MorningBrew" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
LUXURY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/19/luxury-retail-sector-struggles-absorb-pandemic-blow?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Luxury Market on Its Manolo Heels
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="The RealReal luxury bags in a pyramid" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMTEvcHlyYW1pZF9vZl9sdXh1cnlfYmFncy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Remember we wrote how rich people drove the U.S. savings rate to record highs? Well, that's a pretty terrible sign for the luxury industry.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Consulting giant </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/08/coroanvirus-bain-report-on-global-luxury-sales-for-2020-and-beyond.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Bain predicted</a></span><span> global sales of personal luxury goods would fall as much as 60% in the three months ending in June. For the full year, the industry could shrink 20%–35%. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">What’s causing the plunge? The luxury sector hinges on three key high-thread-count seams: </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Personalized service</strong></span><span>, which social distancing measures have rendered...</span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-18/from-savile-row-to-swiss-watches-luxury-s-rules-have-changed?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">much less personal</a></span><span>. One tailor on London’s Savile Row told Bloomberg he had to ask customers to button and pin their own suits, while he took notes and photos from a few feet away. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Tourist traffic</strong></span><span> in shopping meccas like New York, Paris, and Milan has been reduced to a trickle. All eyes will be on the fast-growing Chinese market, which has shown signs of rebounding. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Experience</strong></span><span>. If you’ve ever been to Harrods, you know that luxury shopping is about being swallowed in an alligator-skin fantasy...until you wake up the next morning down $785. It’s hard to replicate that online.</span>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>luxury sales will take a few years to return to 2019 levels, Bain projects, and even that depends on the usual variables: consumer confidence, tourism trends, and overall economic growth.</p>

</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Apple Pay demonstration" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNDMwL2FwcGxlX3BheV9kZW1vbnN0cmF0aW9uLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Apple</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As the coronavirus changed our perception of cash from "boo-ya I've got money" to "why am I carrying around this germ-infested piece of paper?" many shoppers started leaving their cash at home, and some retailers stopped accepting it altogether. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Is this the death of cash? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The pandemic has <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/90d666a2-621e-487e-8048-e86c047bb3c7?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">fundamentally changed</a> how consumers pay for items, Visa’s European chief told the FT. And it's not just that shoppers are using debit and credit cards more: Contactless payments, which use radio-frequency tech or QR codes to pay with taps or scans, are <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/jonmarkman/2020/05/24/pandemic-rings-death-knell-for-paper-cash/#39ae279d5072?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">gaining traction</a>.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Dozens of countries raised their cap on the size of contactless payments allowed.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Walmart and Publix said they’d implement contactless payment options, joining Costco, Target, 7-Eleven, and Amazon Go.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">So what's preventing the cashless revolution?</strong> Installing contactless systems is expensive, especially for small businesses. Consumers also need smartphones to use the tech. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Plus, 6% of U.S. adults are “<a href="https://www.federalreserve.gov/publications/2019-economic-well-being-of-us-households-in-2018-banking-and-credit.htm?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">unbanked</a>,” meaning they do not have a checking, savings, or money market account. And access to banking falls unevenly across racial lines: 4% of white adults are unbanked, compared to 14% of Blacks and 11% of Hispanics, according to data from the Fed. If stores drop cash entirely, millions could get shut out.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The coronavirus has not only transformed what we buy, but <em>how</em> we buy. The transition to digital payments just got a dose of jet fuel. </p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HOME IMPROVEMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/19/home-improvement-sector-surprisingly-well?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
It’s a Bad Time to Be a Squeaky Floorboard
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Hammer flipping" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/B7wuyKVTYe6pG/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Hammer flipping" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/B7wuyKVTYe6pG/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Despite a global retail slowdown, the home improvement sector has been...improving. Stay-at-home orders have prompted bored Americans to level up everything from the duvet to the driveway.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Lowe's </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/20/lowes-beats-home-depot-sales-surge.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">smashed</a></span><span> Q1 earnings expectations, reporting a 28% increase in net income.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Home Depot described “triple-digit” growth in its online business in early April, on top of a 6.4% bump in same-store sales. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But home improvement has made its way past the foyer and into the great outdoors.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Lawns are the place to be</h2>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Inflatable pools, egg-laying chickens, patio furniture, and trampolines are all </span><span><a href="https://www.vox.com/the-goods/21291573/summer-pools-open-inflatable-boat-rental-camps-lawn-coronavirus?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">enjoying noticeable sales bumps</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Americans are discovering gardening like the hunter-gatherers: W. Atlee Burpee & Co., a seed company, had the </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-gardens/home-gardening-blooms-around-the-world-during-coronavirus-lockdowns-idUSKBN2220D3?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">highest sales</a></span><span> of any month in its 144-year history in March.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Pool sharing service Swimply (it’s a real thing) reported a 1,200% increase in bookings between February and March. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> Even before the pandemic, home improvement was proving resistant to retail malaise: Last year, sales were growing at almost <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/bradhunter/2019/07/25/three-reasons-why-home-improvement-is-the-fastest-growing-retail-category-and-what-to-watch-for/#47e5b03d31d7?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">twice the rate</a> of the broader retail sector. That’s likely due to 1) rising home values 2) millennial homeowners' purchasing power and 3) the country's aging housing stock.</p>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nSAVINGS\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/19/us-savings-rate-highest-recordwhy-thats-not-necessarily-good-thing?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nThe United States of Hoarders\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Napoleon Dynamite\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=363 src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/YRo3S2P600PicZhNKX/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"Napoleon Dynamite\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/YRo3S2P600PicZhNKX/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe know we were supposed to write a story about consumer spending during the pandemic, but...that’d just be lying to y’all. Here’s the reality: Americans aren’t spending squat during the pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe U.S. savings rate \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/29/us-savings-rate-hits-record-33percent-as-coronavirus-causes-americans-to-stockpile-cash-curb-spending.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erose to 33%\u003c/a\u003e in April, the highest level on record and it’s not even close. At the same time, consumer spending fell 13.6% (also a record). There are a few reasons why this happened:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThere’s nothing to spend money on. Office work, events, sports, conferences, vacations, weddings, birthday parties, and more were all canceled.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eStimulus checks of up to $1,200 hit millions of households, driving up personal income to record levels.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWith unemployment at 13.3%, Americans are feeling nervous about their job prospects.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBut not all Americans saved equally\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFindings from a Harvard-based research group show that high-income Americans are responsible for \u003ca href=\"https://opportunityinsights.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/tracker-summary.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emost of the reduction\u003c/a\u003e in consumer spending. Lower-income Americans, on the other hand, are now spending nearly as much as they did pre-pandemic—but they’re suffering as the rich hoard their wealth.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAlmost 70% of low-wage workers working in the highest-rent ZIP codes lost their jobs, the researchers note.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy it matters: \u003c/strong\u003eIt further confirms that this recession is one of the weirdest ever. In past downturns people stopped spending on big-ticket items like cars, while keeping up their spending on basic services. That’s flipped this time around, because many of those services (like haircuts) require in-person interactions that can lead to the spread of the virus.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eLooking ahead\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe research is telling us something very important: even if government restrictions were lifted, Americans still wouldn't be spending at pre-pandemic levels out of fear for their health. Which means the NFL could announce tomorrow it’s allowing fans to attend games this season and not many would bite. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eConsumer spending drives nearly 70% of U.S. GDP, so an elevated savings rate could be \u003ca href=\"https://carnegieendowment.org/chinafinancialmarkets/81871?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edetrimental\u003c/a\u003e to the economy in the long-run. After all, writes the Carnegie Endowment, one person’s spending is another person’s income. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOnline grocery sales \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-27/has-online-grocery-shopping-peaked-most-still-prefer-in-store?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erose 200%\u003c/a\u003e year-over-year in March, according to Earnest Research, with Walmart, Amazon, and Instacart all reporting dramatic increases in demand. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“The customer demand we expected over the next two-to-four years on the Instacart platform has happened in the last two-to-four weeks,” said Instacart’s CEO in early April.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSome results of that surge:\u003c/strong\u003e 1) Instacart nabbed a \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/jenniferwang/2020/06/17/instacart-founder-apoorva-mehta-becomes-a-billionaire/#6898a9997e02?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e$13.7 billion\u003c/a\u003e valuation in a recent funding round and 2) Whole Foods and others \u003ca href=\"https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2020/04/how-youll-shop-for-groceries-after-the-pandemic/610135/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erushed\u003c/a\u003e to transition some locations to “dark stores,” micro-fulfillment centers intended exclusively for delivery orders, not in-person shopping. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eAs COVID-19 restrictions ease...\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMany shoppers want to resume playing ripe-avocado roulette in person. CivicScience and Bloomberg found that over one-third of shoppers plan to order groceries online less often as restrictions ease up. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut even as shoppers head back to stores, more have discovered online delivery for the first time and now have the apps on their phones. Kroger CEO Rodney McMullen said this week he thinks habits around home cooking have \u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/kroger-ceo-talks-earnings-digital-172204451.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epermanently changed\u003c/a\u003e because of the coronavirus. savings rate to record highs? Well, that's a pretty terrible sign for the luxury industry.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eConsulting giant \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/08/coroanvirus-bain-report-on-global-luxury-sales-for-2020-and-beyond.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBain predicted\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e global sales of personal luxury goods would fall as much as 60% in the three months ending in June. For the full year, the industry could shrink 20%–35%. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhat’s causing the plunge? The luxury sector hinges on three key high-thread-count seams: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePersonalized service\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, which social distancing measures have rendered...\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-18/from-savile-row-to-swiss-watches-luxury-s-rules-have-changed?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emuch less personal\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. One tailor on London’s Savile Row told Bloomberg he had to ask customers to button and pin their own suits, while he took notes and photos from a few feet away. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTourist traffic\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in shopping meccas like New York, Paris, and Milan has been reduced to a trickle. All eyes will be on the fast-growing Chinese market, which has shown signs of rebounding. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eExperience\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. If you’ve ever been to Harrods, you know that luxury shopping is about being swallowed in an alligator-skin fantasy...until you wake up the next morning down $785. It’s hard to replicate that online.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eluxury sales will take a few years to return to 2019 levels, Bain projects, and even that depends on the usual variables: consumer src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xNDMwL2FwcGxlX3BheV9kZW1vbnN0cmF0aW9uLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eApple\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs the coronavirus changed our perception of cash from \"boo-ya I've got money\" to \"why am I carrying around this germ-infested piece of paper?\" many shoppers started leaving their cash at home, and some retailers stopped accepting it altogether. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIs this the death of cash? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe pandemic has \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/90d666a2-621e-487e-8048-e86c047bb3c7?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efundamentally changed\u003c/a\u003e how consumers pay for items, Visa’s European chief told the FT. And it's not just that shoppers are using debit and credit cards more: Contactless payments, which use radio-frequency tech or QR codes to pay with taps or scans, are \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/jonmarkman/2020/05/24/pandemic-rings-death-knell-for-paper-cash/#39ae279d5072?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003egaining traction\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eDozens of countries raised their cap on the size of contactless payments allowed.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWalmart and Publix said they’d implement contactless payment options, joining Costco, Target, 7-Eleven, and Amazon Go.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSo what's preventing the cashless revolution?\u003c/strong\u003e Installing contactless systems is expensive, especially for small businesses. Consumers also need smartphones to use the tech. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePlus, 6% of U.S. adults are “\u003ca href=\"https://www.federalreserve.gov/publications/2019-economic-well-being-of-us-households-in-2018-banking-and-credit.htm?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunbanked\u003c/a\u003e,” meaning they do not have a checking, savings, or money market account. And access to banking falls unevenly across racial lines: 4% of white adults are unbanked, compared to 14% of Blacks and 11% of Hispanics, according to data from the Fed. If stores drop cash entirely, millions could get shut out.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe coronavirus has not only transformed what we buy, but \u003cem\u003ehow\u003c/em\u003e we buy. The transition to digital payments just got a dose of jet fuel. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/20/lowes-beats-home-depot-sales-surge.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esmashed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Q1 earnings expectations, reporting a 28% increase in net income.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHome Depot described “triple-digit” growth in its online business in early April, on top of a 6.4% bump in same-store sales. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut home improvement style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eInflatable pools, egg-laying chickens, patio furniture, and trampolines are all \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.vox.com/the-goods/21291573/summer-pools-open-inflatable-boat-rental-camps-lawn-coronavirus?utm_source=morning_brew\" bumps\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAmericans are discovering gardening like the hunter-gatherers: W. Atlee Burpee \u0026 Co., a seed company, had the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-gardens/home-gardening-blooms-around-the-world-during-coronavirus-lockdowns-idUSKBN2220D3?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehighest sales\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e of any month in its 144-year history in March.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePool sharing service Swimply (it’s a real thing) reported a 1,200% increase in bookings between February and March. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e Even before the pandemic, home improvement was proving resistant to retail malaise: Last year, sales were growing at almost \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/bradhunter/2019/07/25/three-reasons-why-home-improvement-is-the-fastest-growing-retail-category-and-what-to-watch-for/#47e5b03d31d7?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etwice the rate\u003c/a\u003e of the broader retail sector.
